Tom Dalgleish Someone please tell me the appeal of Superdry
BE11:26am

Following Superdry's disappointing update last week, it is difficult to balance the short-term noise versus the fundamentals. On one hand, it is clear that there was an element of 'one-off' in the weak H1 trading, the business having been impacted by the warm weather given its reliance on outerwear. Conversely, these downgrades reflect the continuation of a well-established multi-year trend for Superdry - that of a sharply declining Retail contribution margin, historically offset by space roll-out and the growing contribution from Wholesale. The 28% fall last week may suggest an over-reaction to the weather impact, but we remain concerned that the root cause is a deeper brand issue and, even with the shares now at a 5yr low and trading on c.8x FY19 PE, we retain our cautious stance.

BE11:27am

We have some sympathy for Superdry. Warm weather during transitional periods hurts this business given its product mix, and we have seen warnings at this time of year before. In addition, there have clearly been some process issues around FX (even if the £8m FX downgrade as a correction to expectations rather than a one off). Outwith the short-term noise, Superdry's challenges, in our view, run much deeper - by the end of FY19, we estimate that Retail contribution margin will have fallen by an incredible 900bp since FY14, impacted by in-store deleverage, dilution from lower margin channels (incl. Zalando), and increased promotional/clearance activity. We remain concerned that these challenges reflect a deeper brand issue, as well as the channel shift. We wrote in July that outperformance from the Wholesale business can only offset these Retail headwinds for so long - looking ahead we believe this remains the case.

Sanctions are the first cousins of tariffs and as the Trump Administration prefers the later, the U.S. Congress prefers the former - and has shown an ability to pass veto-proof legislation in this area over Trump's (and then President Obama's) objections. There are at least three key pieces of legislation that serve as a useful lens in which to view the ongoing saga between the U.S. and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia - outside of potential legislation to prevent arms deals: 1) The Magnitsky Act; 2) Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act (CAATSA); and 3) Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act (JASTA). Given the planned rigid implementation of the Iran crude oil sanctions in two weeks on November 5, the Administration is reliant on the Saudis to offset some of the lost barrels.
Trump made a huge strategic bet on the Saudis and Prince Mohammed bin Salman (MBS), which has created a seemingly inevitable clash with an increasingly anti-Saudi Congress that has shown an ability to buck U.S. Presidents on sanctions - and Saudi - in the past.

The White House has had two years of an incredibly accommodating Congress. Should the House flip to the Democrats in the midterm elections (seems very likely in our minds), this accommodation will be replaced with a full-frontal wave of investigations and subpoenas into all manner of White House and Trump family dealings. We would also anticipate a number of sanctions-related bills that will likely be vetoed by Trump, but will keep these issues front-and-center and devote an inordinate amount of the media's time - and the attention in foreign capitals.

BE11:38am

For the past two years, we have consistently maintained one of the most bullish oil price outlooks on the street. Despite recent
bearish U.S. oil inventory builds, our already bullish 2019/2020 global oil supply/demand model has recently become even more
bullish due largely to deteriorating supply outlooks for both Iranian and Venezuelan exports as well as further clarity on IMO 2020.
After raising our oil price forecast in April and again in July, we are now raising our oil price forecast again – maybe the third time will
be the charm! The bottom line is get ready for triple digit oil prices in the next few years. It is important to note that this is not just
a near-term issue for the next year or two: the picture beyond 2020 continues to suggest higher long-term oil prices after we refine
our assumptions for global oil demand growth, U.S. base decline rates, OPEC production capacity, and non-U.S. supply. Bottom line:
We now believe that oil prices over the
next two years must increase to levels
that are high enough to materially slow
down global demand growth.

BE11:39am

Accordingly, we are raising our 2019 oil
forecast by $10/Bbl (or about 15%), to
$77.50/Bbl WTI and $90/Bbl Brent. We
now think 2020 will be a cyclical peak
year due to IMO 2020, so our forecast
rises even more sharply, to $92.50 WTI
and $100 Brent. Not only is our new
price deck at the high end of consensus,
it is even more strikingly bullish when
compared to the sharply backwardated
futures curve. Specifically, our 2020 oil
price estimates are now about 40%
ABOVE the current futures strip. Beyond
2020, we are also raising our long-term
oil price deck by $5, to $75 WTI and $80
Brent (which is about 30% above strip
pricing).

1) significantly higher than expected
production declines in Venezuela; 2) Iranian export cutbacks that now seem to be much larger than we originally expected, and are
appearing ahead of the return of U.S. sanctions; and 3) increasing clarity on the impact of the International Maritime Organization’s
(IMO’s) 2020 sulfur regulations, which will have a game-changing impact on the oil market. Given the significantly undersupplied
market we expect over the next few years, it is clear that oil prices must rise enough to slow global demand growth even more than we had previously modeled.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

There are three primary reasons that we are raising our oil price forecast for a third time this year: First, Venezuelan oil production
continues to deteriorate at a much faster rate than we had predicted at the beginning of the year. Secondly, the sanctions that the
U.S. has placed upon Iran are already having a much greater impact on Iranian exports/production that we thought just a few
months ago. Finally, it is increasingly clear that the consequences of IMO 2020 will effectively mean a 1 to 2 million bpd reduction in
global oil supplies starting late 2019. The consequences of these lower oil supply estimates are that oil prices must increase to levels
that are sufficiently high to begin meaningfully slowing global demand growth over the next few years.
Accordingly, we are raising our 2019 forecast by $10/Bbl (or ~15%), to $77.50/Bbl WTI and $90/Bbl Brent. For 2020, the cyclical peak
year, our price deck rises even more sharply, to $92.50 WTI and $100 Brent (representing about a 25% increase from our prior
estimates). Beyond 2020, we are raising our price deck by $5, to $75 WTI and $80 Brent. Not only is our new price deck at the high
end of consensus, but it is even more striking when compared to the longer-term backwardated futures curve. Specifically, these
new out-year oil price estimates are now about 30% above current futures “strip” pricing. While we do not think that triple-digit
oil prices will become the new normal, at least temporarily that is what the market should require to squeeze demand out of the
system.

The top line was driven by ancillary revenues, with scheduled revenues +2% yoy and ancillary revenues +29% yoy, in line with the pattern that we have seen over previous months. Cost increases were driven by fuel (+21% yoy) and personnel (+32% yoy), both numbers being close to our estimates.
The company’s comment on union negotiation progress reads as cautiously optimistic:
“While we hope to finalise more union agreements in the coming months, we cannot rule out occasional industrial action, but we expect their impact to be very limited.”
RYA also shares our view that too much capacity is coming into the market this winter (SG Compass): “This full-year guidance remains heavily dependent on air fares not declining further (they remain soft this winter due to excess capacity in Europe)”.

Implications — We have tweaked our net profit forecasts (for costs/fuel), albeit they remain broadly unchanged at EUR1.12bn for FY’19 and EUR1.40bn for FY’20. Our target price also remains unaltered at EUR15.0. Our Buy case remains predicated on a strong FY’20 recovery and we note that the report has a tone of confidence about the medium-term (on consolidation and costs, in particular). Nearterm however, the controversy in the share price will continue to be dominated by a few well-debated forces. The bulls will likely point towards weak YoY comparisons in FY’20, close-to-trough P/E multiples, low asset valuation multiples, a unique market position and a consolidating backdrop. The bears will likely highlight the inflating unit cost base and news flow now blighted by unions & disruption.

BE11:57am

The statement was triggered by rumours that Safestyle might buy Safeglaze, which are apparently untrue. Here's Liberum.

BE11:57am

SafeGlaze was launched early in 2018 by the historic founder of Safestyle and has been a very aggressive new entrant into the UK replacement window market. The direct disruption to Safestyle's lead generation and workforce was the main driver of the 27% drop in Safestyle’s sales in the first half.

Safestyle announced that it reached a settlement with SafeGlaze in September 2018, having launched legal proceedings in May 2018. Under the terms of the settlement, the existing court injunctions were replaced by undertakings to the court and SafeGlaze agreed to rebrand to a new name that will eliminate scope for confusion between the two brands. The settlement related to legal claims made by Safestyle against SafeGlaze, through the Business and Property Courts, seeking injunctive relief and damages. The Group asked the Court to examine claims of "passing off, misuse of confidential information, unlawful means conspiracy and malicious falsehood". At the first hearing on 25 May, the Court (among other things) made a number of injunctive orders preventing SafeGlaze UK and certain named individuals from undertaking various actions.

Dec69 - Skeptic @Excel Developer, that's where I started awhile back, it's quite interesting actually.
11:57 am
BE11:58am

Liberum
UK | BUSINESS SERVICES, BUILDING, LEISURE & TRAVEL | BUILDING MATERIALS & HOUSEBUILDERS | SFE LN | MARKET CAP £42m | 19 October 2018^

Safestyle*

Not buying SafeGlaze

HOLD

Target price 50p | Published price 50p | *Corporate Client of Liberum

In response to speculation, Safestyle’s Board has announced that it is not in discussions to acquire either the assets or business of SafeGlaze, the very aggressive and disruptive new entrant to the industry. However the Board has said it is considering other arrangements with key SafeGlaze stakeholders, and that these could potentially prove beneficial to Safestyle's business and its recovery. We await further developments with interest. The shares now trade at only 6.5x 2020E PER or 2.5x peak earnings, suggesting very significant upside if management can succeed in restoring the Group to historic sales and profit levels.

Safestyle has denied it is in discussion to buy SafeGlaze

Safestyle’s management has announced that it has become aware of rumours that it is in discussion to acquire SafeGlaze, and states that it is not in discussions to acquire either the business or assets of SafeGlaze.

SafeGlaze was launched early in 2018 by the historic founder of Safestyle and has been a very aggressive new entrant into the UK replacement window market. The direct disruption to Safestyle's lead generation and workforce was the main driver of the 27% drop in Safestyle’s sales in the first half.

Safestyle announced that it reached a settlement with SafeGlaze in September 2018, having launched legal proceedings in May 2018. Under the terms of the settlement, the existing court injunctions were replaced by undertakings to the court and SafeGlaze agreed to rebrand to a new name that will eliminate scope for confusion between the two brands. The settlement related to legal claims made by Safestyle against SafeGlaze, through the Business and Property Courts, seeking injunctive relief and damages. The Group asked the Court to examine claims of "passing off, misuse of confidential information, unlawful means conspiracy and malicious falsehood". At the first hearing on 25 May, the Court (among other things) made a number of injunctive orders preventing SafeGlaze UK and certain named individuals from undertaking various actions.

But is considering other arrangements that may prove beneficial

Intriguingly, this morning’s announcement goes on to say that although that Safestyle is not in discussions to buy either the assets or the business of SafeGlaze, it is considering other arrangements with key stakeholders of NIAMAC (the owner of SafeGlaze) that could benefit Safestyle’s business and accelerate its recovery.

We can only speculate what these arrangements may be, but we note management’s comments that there is no certainty that any formal arrangement will be entered into, but that a further announcement will be made in due course. We await developments with interest.

Forester @excel we the fuel in my rotavator definitely degrades - it costs me £5 every spring for a fresh tank!
BE11:58am

We are forecasting a loss before tax of c£6m in 2018, which compares to peak (2016) PBT of £20m. We believe that there is significant recovery potential as Safestyle replaces employees poached by SafeGlaze and market share starts to be recovered and grows once again. This remains a very fragmented industry, with Safestyle having around 9% market share and competitors 2-4 (Anglian, Everest and Safeglaze) having 15-20%. We remain convinced that Safestyle has a significant cost advantage in manufacturing, which should enable momentum in market share to be turned positive once again.

A. M. @Excel: never really thought of oil as having shelf-life.
BE11:59am

We note that the Group made EBITDA of £10m in 2012 when sales were £110m; and we expect EBITDA of -£4m in 2018E from sales of £119m. This shows the scale of the recovery potential.

Tom Dalgleish Diesel degrades with time
11:59 am
BE11:59am

The shares look very cheap at 50p and we believe they could rise to 80p on a two year view [c10x PER 2020E] if the stock market starts to have confidence in the 2020E estimates. We also highlight that at 50p the shares only trade at around 2.5x peak earnings, suggesting very considerable upside if management can successfully rebuild the business to previous levels of activity. We expect a small net debt position at year end [£2m] which should reverse as profitability is rebuilt.
